CHEMISTRY NIGHT CLASSES BIG;
DR. GILPIN SUPERVISING THEM

The night courses in chemistry,
have begun this year with an enrollment of about fifty students,
which is more than twice the number which took these courses last
year. Most of the men and women
taking the courses are employed
during the day in chemical laboratories.
Dr. Joseph E. Gilpin, collegiate
professor of chemistry, is directing the courses in this department.
The laboratory work is under the
direction of Dr. Ellis Miller, instructor in chemistry, and Dr. H.
H. Lloyd, professor of chemistry
in Goucher College.
Two courses are offered, an elementary course in general chemistry and an advanced course in
qualitative and quantitative analysis and organic chemistry. The elementary course has one evening of
lecture and one of laboratory
work each week. The advanced
course has two evenings per week
of laboratory work and lectures
at irregular intervals.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 29, 1917.

ELECTS PROF. WOOD PRESIDENT

BELGIAN WILL LECTURE HERE

DECREASE IN STUDENTS SMALL

Philological Association Enjoys His Inaugural Address, "Opitz and Ronsard:
The Approach to Lte Renaissance Epic."

Prof. Horta to Talk on German Destruction of Buildings in Belgium,
This Thursday in Civil Engineering Building.

Number Seven and One-half Per Cent.
Less Than Last Year-368 Undergraduates, 370 Medical Students
and 153 Graduates.

The Johns Hopkins Philological
Association met for the first time
this year in Gilman Hall on Friday, October 19_ The newlyelected president, Prof. Henry
Wood, delivered his inaugural address and read the principal paper
on "Opitz and Ronsard: The Approach to Late Renaissance Epic."
A minor communication was presented by Professor Haupt.
Professor Wood has been kind
enough to write for THE NEWSLETTER an abstract of his address,
which follows:
The conclusions reached in
this essay may be summarized as
follows: Opitz's "Zlatna" (written 1622) is based, in style, imagery and detail, upon the "Mosella" of Ausonius (A. D. 370).
This novel parallelism points,
however, to the further fact that
the attitude of the two poets towards Roman imperialism and the
world-historic mission of Roman
civilization and culture can be
called identical. Ausonius, the
Gallic provincial at the royal resi(lence Trier (Treves)—at that time
a more important administrative
center than Rome—praised Greater Rome as the basis of all possible European civilization, and
his "Mosella" must be called the
Epic of reminiscence and anticipation, on this theme. Martial's
poem on "Caesar's Tree" at Cordova) was shown to convey an
idea of Greater Rome quite in
harmony with that of Ausonius,
and with very similar imagery
and illustration, from the point of
view of the Spanish provincial.
Opitz, writing in Liebenbiirgen.
the ancient Dacia, with the events
recorded on Trajan's column in
his mind, with Roman monuments
before his eyes, and with the relics
of the "lingua Romana" assailing
his ears, constructed his epic of
reminiscence a n d anticipation
"Zlatna" from a similar point of
view, save that the world in which
he longed to see it realized was to
be a new German literature of distinctly national type, but with latinized amenities of spiritual outlook and poetical expression.
These organic lines of development from Ausonius to Opitz were
then contrasted with Ronsard's dynastic derivation of his eponymous
national hero Francus, through
the Dictys and Dares legend of
Troy, from Hector, son of Priam.
Not content with this conventionalized geneological tree for "La
Pleiade," Ronsard fabled in his
autobiographical notes of an ancestor of his own, from the Lower
Danube, whose journey to France
through Hungary and Germany in
the fourteenth century to the aid
of the French king, Philippe VI,

Dr. David M. Robinson, vicepresident of the Baltimore Society
of the Archaeological Institute of
America, has announced an illustrated lecture that is expected to
be of the greatest interest to the
men of the University. Prof. Victor Horta, A. R. B., of Belgium,
on Thursday, November 1, 1917,
at 4.30 o'clock, in the Civil Engineering Building, will tell of what
the Germans have done to his native land; his subject being "The
Cathedrals and Public Buildings
of Northern France as Affected by
the War."
Though the story of the martyr
country of the Great War is appealing in itself, added interest is
given it by the fact that it is to be
treated by such a prominent man
as Dr. Horta.
Professor Horta is honorary
professor and dean of the Royal
School of Fine Arts, Brussels; a
member of the Academie Belgique,
knight of the Order of De Leopold
and Norton Memorial Lecturer for
1917 on the Loeb Foundation.
Dr. Robinson will preside in the
absence of Dr. Magoffin, who is
now a captain in the Quartermaster's Corps and stationed at
Columbia, S. C.

The latest official figures from
the Registrar's office give the number of undergraduates as 368, the
medical students 370, and the
graduate students 153. Compared
with last year's enrollment, there
is a decrease of 7/
1
2 per cent.,
which is due to the many enlistments. This decrease is principally in the number of graduates.
• Of the new students there are
76 graduates, 149 undergraduates
and 119 medical men. Of the 149
undergraduate freshmen, 85 are
pursuing the acadeplic course, 56
the engineering course and 8 are
special students.
Baltimore City College supplied
nearly 50 freshmen, a larger number than that from any other
school; the Polytechnic Institute
sent 20 men, and the other Baltimore "prep" schools furnished all
together 26 men.
Four of the class officers came
from Baltimore schools. George
Carey, president, and F. E. Pegram, treasurer, studied at the University School for Boys. John
Marcuse, from John Marshall
High School of Richmond, is the
vice-president. R. G. Heiner, secretary, prepped at St. James'
School and Elmer Jones, sergeantat-arms, at Baltimore City College. It has been a noticable fact
that for the first time in many
years only one office in the Freshman Class is held by a City College man instead of them all.

corresponds in all essential particulars with the argonautica of
Francus as described in "La
Franciade" (1572). With these
guiding points in mind, it is readily perceived that Ronsard's poem
is in reality no epic, but a poem
with epic machinery corresponding essentially with the Old
French "Roman de Troie." In
Ronsard's hands the strenuous
imperial Renaissance conception
of Greater Rome, as expressed by
Martial, Ausonius and Opitz, is exchanged for a softer ideal of
French loveliness, "la douceur angevine." French literature, from
"La Franciade" to Voltaire's "La
Henriade," lost through this
change all organic connection
with genuine epic poetry, gaining
instead the lyrics of "La Pleiade,"
which restored to literature "an
all but lost delight." The muse of
Opitz could confer no such magic
gifts, moving as she did through
the lower ranges of poetry. But
by his faithful preservation of
the Renaissance epic idea,. Opitz
in a measure prepared the way for
Goethe. In his "Hermann und
Dorothea," the action of which
takes place, in the very next German province to that in which
Trier is situated, Goethe outdid
the "Mosella" as a Renaissance
epic of reminiscence and anticipation, while adding a new national content, and founding a
new German Classicism.

VIRGINIA FAVORS TRIANGLE;
FRESH-SOPH DEBATE IN VIEW

The University of Virginia has
sent word that it is anxious to restore the annual triangular debate
between Hopkins, Virginia and
North Carolina, and it is very
probable that North Carolina will
very soon make known its willingness to do likewise. Consequently,
the outlook for debating is brighter than it has been for sometime.
The Debating Council will hold a
meeting next week to decide upon
a subject and to make final arrangements. The subject finally
decided upon and the date for
tryouts will be announced in THE

NEWS-LETTER.
The idea of a freshman team
and a freshman-sophomore debate
has proved evry popular, and there
is a strong possibility that the
idea will materialize. Committees from the two lower classes
will meet Dr. French and Charles
Leber, '20, who represents the
Council, to complete arrangements.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 29, 1917.

URGES GETTING INTO THE GAME
Subject of Dr. Loren Edwards at MassMeeting—Drs. Ames and Raney
Also Speak—Sophomores
Show Spirit.

Professor Ames and Dr. Raney,
of the University, and Dr. Loren
Edwards, pastor of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church and a former football, baseball and basketball star, were the three speakers
at the mass-meeting last Friday
in the Civil Engineering Building.
The meeting was much better attended than usual, because the
whole Sophomore Class appeared
in force, and worked up enthusiasm by their cheering.
Alec Wolfe, who presided,
noticed this fact and complimented them on their fine example of
college,spirit. He then introduced
Dr. Ames, who is at the head of
the Baltimore branch of the association working for the Library
Fund.
He told of the necessity of keeping soldiers in touch with the civil
life in which they were engaged
before entering the service, and to
which they will return after the
war, and said that the only way
to accomplish this was to give
them books. He appealed to the
Hopkins students as educated
men to support this cause and
told how the trustees of the University, Goucher, the Hopkins
Medical School and the preparatory schools in Baltimore had responded generously to the appeal.
Dr. Raney then gave statistics
showing that every branch of the
University had subscribed its
quota except the undergraduate
body, and urged those who had
not subscribed to do so immediately.
Dr. Edwards, of Grace M. E.
Church delivered a talk urging
the fellows to put aside selfconsciousness and to "get into the
game," as he termed it. He then
told of the value of teamwork and
stated that individual "stars"
counted but little without co-operation. In closing, he said that the
fellow who obeys well will soon
be able to lead well and that foresight in all things is essential to
success.
Coach Brennick concluded the
meeting with a short talk on the
prospects of the game with Carlisle, asking for the support of
thestudents.
Donovan Room for Study Hall.

The Student Council has secured from the faculty the privilege of using the lower end of the
Donovan Room for a study hall.
This is intended to replace in part
the far corner of the old library
in McCoy Hall, where students
were wont to gather and in
lowered voices discuss the issues
of the day.

BALTIMORE, MARYLAND,
OCTOBER 25, 1917.
DR. FRANK J. GOODNOW,
Johns Hopkins University, City.
DEAR DR. GOODNOW :
Will you thank the Johns Hopkins men on behalf of the
Liberty Loan Committee and the Board of Trade of Baltimore
City for the splendid showing they made in the Liberty Loan
Parade and Pageant last night. All of us connected with Hopkins
were very proud of them.
Faithfully yours,
B. HOWELL GRISWOLD, Chairman.

BATTALION IS CONGRATULATED
Commended for Splendid Showing in
Liberty Loan Parade—Members Can
Receive Ration Fee—Colors
Needed.

Captain Guild and the members
of the battalion have received congratulations on the showing of the
corps in the Liberty Loan parade
on Wednesday, October 24. Evidence of this is shown in the letter appearing above. Captain
Guild had readily accepted the
request that the corps take part
in the patriotic exhibition, and at
7.30 last Wednesday evening the
corps was lined up at attention
on St. Paul street, waiting for the
word to march.
Though just starting on its year
of training and containing a large
proportion of green men, the Hopkins corps was able by its soldierly appearance and precision in
holding lines to call forth cheers
all along the line of march. In
the general orders of October 25th,
the commandant commended the
battalion on its excellent showing
in the parade, especially complimenting Company B for its excellent attendance record.
Members of the Hopkins battalion who are candidates for commissions in the Reserve Corps of
the Army will in future, during
the third and fourth year of training, receive pay at the rate of 30
cents a day ration fee, according
to information received by Captain Guild from the War Department. Certificate of training in
the Reserve Officers' Training
Corps at another institution of
good standing will be -considered
equivalent to training here.
In the memorandum in which
the above announcement is made,
Captain Guild remarks: "From
the above it will be noted that the
Reserve Officers' Training Corps
at this institution is a United
States government body of troops
to a certain degree, in that the
Government is willing to pay and
will pay for the service which the
students put into military training after the first two years of
that training."
Captain Guild expects rapid
progress in military training from
now on. The recruits have now
been assigned to the regular companies and orders have already

Y. M. C. A. ELECTS OFFICERS;
LEBER APPOINTED PRESIDENT

An election of officers of the Y.
M. C. A. to take up the work of
those who left the University last
spring was held last Monday afternoon immediately after the chapel
service. Several new committee
chairmen for this year have also
recently been appointed, so that
the Cabinet as it now stands complete consists of:
Officers—President, Charles T.
Leber, '20; vice-president, Roszel
C. Thomsen, '19; corresponding
secretary, William L. Merriken,
'20; recording secretary, Stephen
Orne, '20; treasurer, Harris E.
Kirk, Jr., '19.
Committee Chairmen — Bible
studies, Roszel C. Thomsen, '19;
chapel, Warren W. Almy, '20;
community service, H. H. Mercereau, '20; deputation work, Edward Hoffmeister, '20; membership, Ronald A. Cox, '19; midweek meetings, Douglas Coulter,
'20; music, Oscar W. McCleary,
'20; reading-room, S. E. Abrams,
'20; social, Vernon E. Stuart, '20.
CULLUM, STUDENT ASSISTANT

K. S. Cullum, a senior in sanitary engineering, has been appointed student assistant in engineering drawing by associate
professor G. R. Jones, of the civil
engineering department.
been issued for the drawing and
cleaning of guns. It is expected that only a few weeks will
elapse before the routine work of
elementary training is accomplished, and the more interesting
advanced work is begun.
There has been considerable discussion, among the men since the
the parade last Wednesday, with
regard to a distinctive color for
the battalion. This need was emphasized by the difficulty spectators had in giving the right name
to the battalion while on the
march. The unit was taken for
everything f rom preparatory
school cadets to a part of the
Regular Army. Designs are being

will be soon provided.

OFFERS INTERESTING SUBJECTS
B. S. Degree Given in Teachers' College
Courses for Sufficient Number
of Points—Open to Undergraduates.

The college courses for teachers,
which commenced this year officially on October 18, include
some of the most interesting and
important groups of courses being given in the University. With
an enrollment of well over three
hundred, they far surpass in point
of numbers either the engineering school or .the academic department. The degree of bachelor of
science is given to those enrolled
in the teachers' courses who complete sufficient courses to obtain
the required number of credits.
Despite the war situation, the
number of candidates for the degree has increased over that of
last year.
The courses are open to undergraduate students, about twenty
of whom have availed themselves
of the opportunity. A number of
these are engineering students
who are taking one or another of
the English courses. A number
of graduate students, including
several from the Medical School,
are also enrolled, many of them
endeavoring in this way to pass
off a condition which stands in
the way of a doctor's degree. The
majority of the graduates are taking French or German.
Dr. Buchner, the director of the
teachers' courses, in an interview
with a representative of THE
NEWS-LETTER, pointed out the
many occupations represented by
those attending the classes. "In
addition to teachers," he said,
"and to the undergraduate, graduate and Medical School students,
there are enrolled State and city
officials, lawyers, engineers, physicians, nurses and clergymen."
Thirty-four courses are given
this year, some in the afternoon
and some at night. They include
courses in art, chemistry, philosophy, history, education, political
science, political economy, drawing, English, French, German,
Spanish and Oriental languages.
The new courses are highly interesting. Dr. Slonimsky is conducting one on the history of philosophy; Dr. Latane will give another in American diplomacy; and
a third will be under the leadership of Dr. Robinson, on Greek
sculpture. In co-operation with
the Baltimore Board of School
Commissioners, Dr. Gilpin has introduced a night course in organic
chemistry for domestic science
teachers. There will also be a survey course in English literature,
under Dr;Powell; a course in European drama, under Dr. Gay; a
class conducted by Dean Brush on
French literature since 1870; another in practical French, under
Dr. Grfinbaum, formed by special
request; and a course in drawing.

Sir—To be mistaken for a detachment of the National Army
is no inconsiderable compliment
for our military training corps,
no doubt. Nor are we anything
but pleased on learning of the
various other excellent organizations for which our battalion was
mistaken on the night of the Liberty Loan parade. The three companies certainly did excellent
work in the parade, and it is only
natural that spectators should
have expressed their approval in
such a manner.
But this almost universal misapprehension as to the identity of
the Hopkins corps should remind
us of one thing very strongly—
that the distinguishing insignia
to be worn by individual members
of the corps, which Captain Guild
has so thoughtfully provided,
while entirely adequate for the

have signified their intention of
joining the Union. • The dues for
college memberships are classified
according to the size of the college; so that Hopkins is particularly fortunate in having to pay
the minimum rate of $100 a year.
This sum will be raised by the
students, who will themselves
reap the benefits of the organization when they get their chance
to go "over there."
The honorary patrons of the
American University Union in
Europe are: The Secretary of
War, the Secretary of the Navy,
the American Ambassador to
France and the general commanding the American forces in
France. The active officers are
men affiliated with large American colleges and universities.

TRACK SQUAD NEEDS MORE MEN
Cross Country Club of Baltimore Training With Team on Saturdays.
S. A. I. A. A. Plans Being
Carried Out.

Fall training for the track
squad is well under way, and
about fifteen men have been covering the two-mile cross-country
course nearly every afternoon.
More men are needed at once,
however, to make it possible for
Hopkins to carry out its fall
plans. Training is held every day
but Monday at 4.30 P. M.
On last Saturday afternoon,
members of the Cross Country
Club of Baltimore ran over the
course with the squad and showed
them a few points about the run.
They are to practice every Saturday afternoon with Hopkins men
and help train them.
All arrangements for the South
Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association cross - country run,
which takes place on November
24, have about been completed and
invitations have been sent out to
all the colleges which are members of the Association. The
Georgia Institute of Technology,
which was elected to the Association last year, expects to take an
active part in coming competitions. More candidates for the
team must appear, if Hopkins is
to be successful in this meet.
Besides a call for more runners,
an appeal is made for candidates
for the office of assistant managers. All who wish to come out
for either the team or management are asked to give their
names to the manager.

CHEMISTRY NIGHT CLASSES BIG;
DR. GILPIN SUPERVISING THEM

The night courses in chemistry,
have begun this year with an enrollment of about fifty students,
which is more than twice the number which took these courses last
year. Most of the men and women
taking the courses are employed
during the day in chemical laboratories.
Dr. Joseph E. Gilpin, collegiate
professor of chemistry, is directing the courses in this department.
The laboratory work is under the
direction of Dr. Ellis Miller, instructor in chemistry, and Dr. H.
H. Lloyd, professor of chemistry
in Goucher College.
Two courses are offered, an elementary course in general chemistry and an advanced course in
qualitative and quantitative analysis and organic chemistry. The elementary course has one evening of
lecture and one of laboratory
work each week. The advanced
course has two evenings per week
of laboratory work and lectures
at irregular intervals.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 29, 1917.

3

ELECTS PROF. WOOD PRESIDENT

BELGIAN WILL LECTURE HERE

DECREASE IN STUDENTS SMALL

Philological Association Enjoys His Inaugural Address, "Opitz and Ronsard:
The Approach to Lte Renaissance Epic."

Prof. Horta to Talk on German Destruction of Buildings in Belgium,
This Thursday in Civil Engineering Building.

Number Seven and One-half Per Cent.
Less Than Last Year-368 Undergraduates, 370 Medical Students
and 153 Graduates.

The Johns Hopkins Philological
Association met for the first time
this year in Gilman Hall on Friday, October 19_ The newlyelected president, Prof. Henry
Wood, delivered his inaugural address and read the principal paper
on "Opitz and Ronsard: The Approach to Late Renaissance Epic."
A minor communication was presented by Professor Haupt.
Professor Wood has been kind
enough to write for THE NEWSLETTER an abstract of his address,
which follows:
The conclusions reached in
this essay may be summarized as
follows: Opitz's "Zlatna" (written 1622) is based, in style, imagery and detail, upon the "Mosella" of Ausonius (A. D. 370).
This novel parallelism points,
however, to the further fact that
the attitude of the two poets towards Roman imperialism and the
world-historic mission of Roman
civilization and culture can be
called identical. Ausonius, the
Gallic provincial at the royal resi(lence Trier (Treves)—at that time
a more important administrative
center than Rome—praised Greater Rome as the basis of all possible European civilization, and
his "Mosella" must be called the

These organic lines of development from Ausonius to Opitz were

Not content with this conventionalized geneological tree for "La

Dr. David M. Robinson, vicepresident of the Baltimore Society
of the Archaeological Institute of
America, has announced an illustrated lecture that is expected to
be of the greatest interest to the
men of the University. Prof. Victor Horta, A. R. B., of Belgium,
on Thursday, November 1, 1917,
at 4.30 o'clock, in the Civil Engineering Building, will tell of what
the Germans have done to his native land; his subject being "The
Cathedrals and Public Buildings
of Northern France as Affected by
the War."
Though the story of the martyr
country of the Great War is appealing in itself, added interest is
given it by the fact that it is to be
treated by such a prominent man
as Dr. Horta.
Professor Horta is honorary
professor and dean of the Royal
School of Fine Arts, Brussels; a
member of the Academie Belgique,
knight of the Order of De Leopold
and Norton Memorial Lecturer for
1917 on the Loeb Foundation.
Dr. Robinson will preside in the
absence of Dr. Magoffin, who is
now a captain in the Quartermaster's Corps and stationed at
Columbia, S. C.

The latest official figures from
the Registrar's office give the number of undergraduates as 368, the
medical students 370, and the
graduate students 153. Compared
with last year's enrollment, there
is a decrease of 7/
1
2 per cent.,
which is due to the many enlistments. This decrease is principally in the number of graduates.
• Of the new students there are
76 graduates, 149 undergraduates
and 119 medical men. Of the 149
undergraduate freshmen, 85 are
pursuing the acadeplic course, 56
the engineering course and 8 are
special students.
Baltimore City College supplied
nearly 50 freshmen, a larger number than that from any other
school; the Polytechnic Institute
sent 20 men, and the other Baltimore "prep" schools furnished all
together 26 men.
Four of the class officers came
from Baltimore schools. George
Carey, president, and F. E. Pegram, treasurer, studied at the University School for Boys. John
Marcuse, from John Marshall
High School of Richmond, is the
vice-president. R. G. Heiner, secretary, prepped at St. James'
School and Elmer Jones, sergeantat-arms, at Baltimore City College. It has been a noticable fact
that for the first time in many
years only one office in the Freshman Class is held by a City College man instead of them all.

Francus as described in "La
Franciade" (1572). With these
guiding points in mind, it is readily perceived that Ronsard's poem
is in reality no epic, but a poem
with epic machinery corresponding essentially with the Old
French "Roman de Troie." In
Ronsard's hands the strenuous
imperial Renaissance conception
of Greater Rome, as expressed by
Martial, Ausonius and Opitz, is exchanged for a softer ideal of
French loveliness, "la douceur angevine." French literature, from
"La Franciade" to Voltaire's "La
Henriade," lost through this
change all organic connection
with genuine epic poetry, gaining
instead the lyrics of "La Pleiade,"
which restored to literature "an
all but lost delight." The muse of
Opitz could confer no such magic
gifts, moving as she did through
the lower ranges of poetry. But
by his faithful preservation of
the Renaissance epic idea,. Opitz
in a measure prepared the way for
Goethe. In his "Hermann und
Dorothea," the action of which
takes place, in the very next German province to that in which
Trier is situated, Goethe outdid
the "Mosella" as a Renaissance
epic of reminiscence and anticipation, while adding a new national content, and founding a
new German Classicism.

VIRGINIA FAVORS TRIANGLE;
FRESH-SOPH DEBATE IN VIEW

The University of Virginia has
sent word that it is anxious to restore the annual triangular debate
between Hopkins, Virginia and
North Carolina, and it is very
probable that North Carolina will
very soon make known its willingness to do likewise. Consequently,
the outlook for debating is brighter than it has been for sometime.
The Debating Council will hold a
meeting next week to decide upon
a subject and to make final arrangements. The subject finally
decided upon and the date for
tryouts will be announced in THE

NEWS-LETTER.
The idea of a freshman team
and a freshman-sophomore debate
has proved evry popular, and there
is a strong possibility that the
idea will materialize. Committees from the two lower classes
will meet Dr. French and Charles
Leber, '20, who represents the
Council, to complete arrangements.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 29, 1917.

URGES GETTING INTO THE GAME
Subject of Dr. Loren Edwards at MassMeeting—Drs. Ames and Raney
Also Speak—Sophomores
Show Spirit.

Professor Ames and Dr. Raney,
of the University, and Dr. Loren
Edwards, pastor of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church and a former football, baseball and basketball star, were the three speakers
at the mass-meeting last Friday
in the Civil Engineering Building.
The meeting was much better attended than usual, because the
whole Sophomore Class appeared
in force, and worked up enthusiasm by their cheering.
Alec Wolfe, who presided,
noticed this fact and complimented them on their fine example of
college,spirit. He then introduced
Dr. Ames, who is at the head of
the Baltimore branch of the association working for the Library
Fund.
He told of the necessity of keeping soldiers in touch with the civil
life in which they were engaged
before entering the service, and to
which they will return after the
war, and said that the only way
to accomplish this was to give
them books. He appealed to the
Hopkins students as educated
men to support this cause and
told how the trustees of the University, Goucher, the Hopkins
Medical School and the preparatory schools in Baltimore had responded generously to the appeal.
Dr. Raney then gave statistics
showing that every branch of the
University had subscribed its
quota except the undergraduate
body, and urged those who had
not subscribed to do so immediately.
Dr. Edwards, of Grace M. E.
Church delivered a talk urging
the fellows to put aside selfconsciousness and to "get into the
game," as he termed it. He then
told of the value of teamwork and
stated that individual "stars"
counted but little without co-operation. In closing, he said that the
fellow who obeys well will soon
be able to lead well and that foresight in all things is essential to
success.
Coach Brennick concluded the
meeting with a short talk on the
prospects of the game with Carlisle, asking for the support of
thestudents.
Donovan Room for Study Hall.

The Student Council has secured from the faculty the privilege of using the lower end of the
Donovan Room for a study hall.
This is intended to replace in part
the far corner of the old library
in McCoy Hall, where students
were wont to gather and in
lowered voices discuss the issues
of the day.

BALTIMORE, MARYLAND,
OCTOBER 25, 1917.
DR. FRANK J. GOODNOW,
Johns Hopkins University, City.
DEAR DR. GOODNOW :
Will you thank the Johns Hopkins men on behalf of the
Liberty Loan Committee and the Board of Trade of Baltimore
City for the splendid showing they made in the Liberty Loan
Parade and Pageant last night. All of us connected with Hopkins
were very proud of them.
Faithfully yours,
B. HOWELL GRISWOLD, Chairman.

BATTALION IS CONGRATULATED
Commended for Splendid Showing in
Liberty Loan Parade—Members Can
Receive Ration Fee—Colors
Needed.

Captain Guild and the members
of the battalion have received congratulations on the showing of the
corps in the Liberty Loan parade
on Wednesday, October 24. Evidence of this is shown in the letter appearing above. Captain
Guild had readily accepted the
request that the corps take part
in the patriotic exhibition, and at
7.30 last Wednesday evening the
corps was lined up at attention
on St. Paul street, waiting for the
word to march.
Though just starting on its year
of training and containing a large
proportion of green men, the Hopkins corps was able by its soldierly appearance and precision in
holding lines to call forth cheers
all along the line of march. In
the general orders of October 25th,
the commandant commended the
battalion on its excellent showing
in the parade, especially complimenting Company B for its excellent attendance record.
Members of the Hopkins battalion who are candidates for commissions in the Reserve Corps of
the Army will in future, during
the third and fourth year of training, receive pay at the rate of 30
cents a day ration fee, according
to information received by Captain Guild from the War Department. Certificate of training in
the Reserve Officers' Training
Corps at another institution of
good standing will be -considered
equivalent to training here.
In the memorandum in which
the above announcement is made,
Captain Guild remarks: "From
the above it will be noted that the
Reserve Officers' Training Corps
at this institution is a United
States government body of troops
to a certain degree, in that the
Government is willing to pay and
will pay for the service which the
students put into military training after the first two years of
that training."
Captain Guild expects rapid
progress in military training from
now on. The recruits have now
been assigned to the regular companies and orders have already

Y. M. C. A. ELECTS OFFICERS;
LEBER APPOINTED PRESIDENT

An election of officers of the Y.
M. C. A. to take up the work of
those who left the University last
spring was held last Monday afternoon immediately after the chapel
service. Several new committee
chairmen for this year have also
recently been appointed, so that
the Cabinet as it now stands complete consists of:
Officers—President, Charles T.
Leber, '20; vice-president, Roszel
C. Thomsen, '19; corresponding
secretary, William L. Merriken,
'20; recording secretary, Stephen
Orne, '20; treasurer, Harris E.
Kirk, Jr., '19.
Committee Chairmen — Bible
studies, Roszel C. Thomsen, '19;
chapel, Warren W. Almy, '20;
community service, H. H. Mercereau, '20; deputation work, Edward Hoffmeister, '20; membership, Ronald A. Cox, '19; midweek meetings, Douglas Coulter,
'20; music, Oscar W. McCleary,
'20; reading-room, S. E. Abrams,
'20; social, Vernon E. Stuart, '20.
CULLUM, STUDENT ASSISTANT

K. S. Cullum, a senior in sanitary engineering, has been appointed student assistant in engineering drawing by associate
professor G. R. Jones, of the civil
engineering department.
been issued for the drawing and
cleaning of guns. It is expected that only a few weeks will
elapse before the routine work of
elementary training is accomplished, and the more interesting
advanced work is begun.
There has been considerable discussion, among the men since the
the parade last Wednesday, with
regard to a distinctive color for
the battalion. This need was emphasized by the difficulty spectators had in giving the right name
to the battalion while on the
march. The unit was taken for
everything f rom preparatory
school cadets to a part of the
Regular Army. Designs are being
cohsidered for a distinctive battalion flag, and it is hoped that it
will be soon provided.

OFFERS INTERESTING SUBJECTS
B. S. Degree Given in Teachers' College
Courses for Sufficient Number
of Points—Open to Undergraduates.

The college courses for teachers,
which commenced this year officially on October 18, include
some of the most interesting and
important groups of courses being given in the University. With
an enrollment of well over three
hundred, they far surpass in point
of numbers either the engineering school or .the academic department. The degree of bachelor of
science is given to those enrolled
in the teachers' courses who complete sufficient courses to obtain
the required number of credits.
Despite the war situation, the
number of candidates for the degree has increased over that of
last year.
The courses are open to undergraduate students, about twenty
of whom have availed themselves
of the opportunity. A number of
these are engineering students
who are taking one or another of
the English courses. A number
of graduate students, including
several from the Medical School,
are also enrolled, many of them
endeavoring in this way to pass
off a condition which stands in
the way of a doctor's degree. The
majority of the graduates are taking French or German.
Dr. Buchner, the director of the
teachers' courses, in an interview
with a representative of THE
NEWS-LETTER, pointed out the
many occupations represented by
those attending the classes. "In
addition to teachers," he said,
"and to the undergraduate, graduate and Medical School students,
there are enrolled State and city
officials, lawyers, engineers, physicians, nurses and clergymen."
Thirty-four courses are given
this year, some in the afternoon
and some at night. They include
courses in art, chemistry, philosophy, history, education, political
science, political economy, drawing, English, French, German,
Spanish and Oriental languages.
The new courses are highly interesting. Dr. Slonimsky is conducting one on the history of philosophy; Dr. Latane will give another in American diplomacy; and
a third will be under the leadership of Dr. Robinson, on Greek
sculpture. In co-operation with
the Baltimore Board of School
Commissioners, Dr. Gilpin has introduced a night course in organic
chemistry for domestic science
teachers. There will also be a survey course in English literature,
under Dr;Powell; a course in European drama, under Dr. Gay; a
class conducted by Dean Brush on
French literature since 1870; another in practical French, under
Dr. Grfinbaum, formed by special
request; and a course in drawing.

Sir—To be mistaken for a detachment of the National Army
is no inconsiderable compliment
for our military training corps,
no doubt. Nor are we anything
but pleased on learning of the
various other excellent organizations for which our battalion was
mistaken on the night of the Liberty Loan parade. The three companies certainly did excellent
work in the parade, and it is only
natural that spectators should
have expressed their approval in
such a manner.
But this almost universal misapprehension as to the identity of
the Hopkins corps should remind
us of one thing very strongly—
that the distinguishing insignia
to be worn by individual members
of the corps, which Captain Guild
has so thoughtfully provided,
while entirely adequate for the

have signified their intention of
joining the Union. • The dues for
college memberships are classified
according to the size of the college; so that Hopkins is particularly fortunate in having to pay
the minimum rate of $100 a year.
This sum will be raised by the
students, who will themselves
reap the benefits of the organization when they get their chance
to go "over there."
The honorary patrons of the
American University Union in
Europe are: The Secretary of
War, the Secretary of the Navy,
the American Ambassador to
France and the general commanding the American forces in
France. The active officers are
men affiliated with large American colleges and universities.

TRACK SQUAD NEEDS MORE MEN
Cross Country Club of Baltimore Training With Team on Saturdays.
S. A. I. A. A. Plans Being
Carried Out.

Fall training for the track
squad is well under way, and
about fifteen men have been covering the two-mile cross-country
course nearly every afternoon.
More men are needed at once,
however, to make it possible for
Hopkins to carry out its fall
plans. Training is held every day
but Monday at 4.30 P. M.
On last Saturday afternoon,
members of the Cross Country
Club of Baltimore ran over the
course with the squad and showed
them a few points about the run.
They are to practice every Saturday afternoon with Hopkins men
and help train them.
All arrangements for the South
Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association cross - country run,
which takes place on November
24, have about been completed and
invitations have been sent out to
all the colleges which are members of the Association. The
Georgia Institute of Technology,
which was elected to the Association last year, expects to take an
active part in coming competitions. More candidates for the
team must appear, if Hopkins is
to be successful in this meet.
Besides a call for more runners,
an appeal is made for candidates
for the office of assistant managers. All who wish to come out
for either the team or management are asked to give their
names to the manager.
